message.content:
Read ~/.claude/docs/kenkai-exclusive.md and extract all the course URLs or course identifiers from the "Hacker" section. These are the reverse engineering courses we need to crawl:
- Extract Chrome Extensions
- Extract Electron Apps  
- JavaScript Deobfuscation
- Extract macOS Apps
- Reverse Engineering Tools
- Terminal Scripts & Hacks
- Web Scraping & Data Extraction
- API Reverse Engineering
- Browser Automation

Figure out the URL pattern for individual courses (likely /exclusive/hacker/course-slug format)

content.text: I'll read the file and extract the course URLs from the Hacker section.

file.content:
# Ken Kai - Exclusives

**Source:** https://www.kenkais.com/exclusive

[Ken Kai's](/)

Pomodoro

Chat

50

[data-protected] code,
[data-protected] pre,
[data-protected] [data-allow-copy] {
user-select: text !important;
-webkit-user-select: text !important;
-moz-user-select: text !important;
-ms-user-select: text !important;
}
@media print {
[data-protected] {
display: none !important;
}
body::after {
content: "This content is protected and cannot be printed.";
display: block;
padding: 2rem;
text-align: center;
font-size: 1.5rem;
}
}

# EXCLUSIVE

40 items

Premium content, courses, and exclusive builds for the community.

New Here?

AllGetting StartedPromptingFirst ProjectBackendSecurityDeploymentBoilerplatesHacker

## Getting Started

8 items

Getting Started

1

### Why Learn This

Before you start: why building with code beats no-code platforms. The skills that last forever vs platforms that don't.

beginnerphilosophyno-code+2

Start Course

Getting Started

2

### What You Can Build

Way more than websites. Voice agents, automation systems, internal tools, SaaS. Stuff that used to need a dev team.

voice agentsautomationsaas+3

Start Course

Getting Started

3

### GitHub & Repositories

How GitHub works and why it matters. Clone, fork, branch, merge, and use GitHub Actions. The foundation for any codebase.

githubgitrepositories+3

Start Course

Getting Started

4

### Terminal Basics

The terminal looks scary but it's actually simple. Everything you need to know to stop being intimidated by it.

terminalcommand linebeginner+4

Start Course

Getting Started

5

### Complete Mac Setup

Everything you need to get your Mac ready for development. Terminal basics, Homebrew, Git, Node.js, and Claude Code - all in one guide.

claude codemacmacos+6

Start Course

Getting Started

6

### Complete Windows Setup (WSL)

Everything you need to get Windows ready for development. WSL, Ubuntu, Git, Node.js, and Claude Code - complete beginner guide.

claude codewindowswsl+6

Start Course

Getting Started

7

### iTerm2 + Oh My Zsh

The terminal setup that developers actually use. Better than the default Mac terminal in every way.

terminalmacshell+3

Start Course

Getting Started

8

### Terminal Customization

Make your terminal actually useful. Nano config, zsh plugins, keybindings, git setup, and aliases that save time.

terminalzshnano+4

Start Course

## Prompting

3 items

Prompting

1

### Design Speak

Learn to describe layouts, colors, spacing, and visual design to your coding agent.

stylingcsstailwind+4

Start Course

Prompting

2

### Code Speak

Learn to describe logic, data, and functionality to your coding agent.

codingtypescriptpython+4

Start Course

Prompting

3

### Simple Prompting

How to prompt AI effectively by keeping it simple. Less is more - learn why complex prompts hurt more than help.

promptingaiclaude+3

Start Course

## First Project

4 items

First Project

1

### Creating Your First Project

The first step: create a project folder, open VS Code, and launch Claude Code. Everything starts here.

beginnersetupterminal+2

Start Course

First Project

2

### Setting Up Your Project

Get the scaffold ready: create a Next.js app, update dependencies, set up code quality, and organize the structure.

nextjsscaffoldprettier+2

Start Course

First Project

3

### Building Your Landing Page

Build a complete landing page with a design system, Shadcn components, and proper accessibility. Your first real project.

landing pageshadcndesign system+2

Start Course

First Project

4

### Deploying to Vercel

Put your landing page on the internet. Create a Vercel account, connect GitHub, and deploy with a few clicks.

deploymentvercelhosting+2

Start Course

## Backend

4 items

Backend

1

### Database Setup

Get Postgres running and connected to your app. Railway makes this dead simple.

postgresdatabaserailway+2

Start Course

Backend

2

### Authentication Setup

Add user login to your Next.js app with NextAuth. OAuth, sessions, protected routes.

authnextauthlogin+2

Start Course

Backend

3

### API Integrations

Connect your app to any API. YouTube, Stripe, crypto prices. Give Claude the docs and it handles the rest.

apiintegrationsfetch+2

Start Course

Backend

4

### Automations

Build automated workflows with code. Cron jobs, webhooks, pipelines. All built by Claude Code.

automationcronwebhooks+2

Start Course

## Security

4 items

Security

1

### Security Pre-Production Checklist

The stuff you need to check before going live. Prompts for your coding agent to find and fix security issues.

securityauditproduction+2

Start Course

Security

2

### Environment Variables & Secrets

How to handle API keys, passwords, and secrets. The stuff that costs people thousands when they get it wrong.

secretsenvapi keys+2

Start Course

Security

3

### API Security Basics

Protect your API endpoints. Prompts that help your coding agent build secure APIs that don't leak data.

apiauthenticationauthorization+2

Start Course

Security

4

### Input Validation & Sanitization

Never trust user input. Prompts that protect you from SQL injection, XSS, and other input-based attacks.

validationsanitizationsql injection+2

Start Course

## Deployment

3 items

Deployment

1

### Choosing Your Deployment Platform

Figure out which platform to use for your project. Vercel, Railway, or both? Depends on what you're building.

deploymentvercelrailway+4

Start Course

Deployment

2

### Deploy with Vercel

Everything you need to deploy your frontend or Next.js app. CLI setup, environment variables, custom domains, and troubleshooting.

verceldeploymentnextjs+4

Start Course

Deployment

3

### Deploy with Railway

Everything you need to deploy backends, APIs, and databases. CLI setup, database provisioning, environment variables, and troubleshooting.

railwaydeploymentbackend+5

Start Course

## Boilerplates

5 items

Boilerplates

1

### Welcome to Boilerplates

What boilerplates are and why developers pay serious money for them. The head start you never knew you needed.

introboilerplatebeginner+1

Start Course

Boilerplates

8

6

2

### Ken's iOS Boilerplate

Production-ready iOS starter template. Auth, Face ID, theming, networking, database, all pre-built. Skip weeks of setup.

iosswiftiphone+2

[View](https://github.com/KenKaiii/kens-ios-app)Course

Boilerplates

7

8

3

### Ken's Chrome Extension Boilerplate

Production-ready Chrome extension template. Manifest V3, TypeScript, React 18, Vite, all pre-configured. Skip the boilerplate and start building.

chromeextensiontypescript+2

[View](https://github.com/KenKaiii/kens-chrome-extension)Course

Boilerplates

1

3

4

### Ken's Discord Boilerplate

Production-ready Discord bot template. Discord.js v14, TypeScript, ESM, automatic command and event handlers. Skip the setup and start building.

discordbottypescript+2

[View](https://github.com/KenKaiii/kens-discord-boilerplate)Course

Boilerplates

0

0

New

5

### Ken's Links Boilerplate

Modern link-in-bio page template. Next.js 16, React 19, Tailwind CSS v4, Framer Motion. One config file to customize everything.

nextjsreacttailwind+3

[View](https://github.com/KenKaiii/kens-links-boilerplate)Course

## Hacker

9 items

Hacker

1

### Extract Chrome Extensions

Get the source code of any Chrome extension. View, download, and analyze extension internals.

chromeextensioncrx+2

Start Course

Hacker

2

### Extract Electron Apps

Unpack any Electron app to get its source code. Discord, Slack, VS Code - they're all just JavaScript.

electronasardesktop+2

Start Course

Hacker

3

### JavaScript Deobfuscation

Turn unreadable minified/obfuscated JavaScript back into readable code. Essential for understanding any web app.

javascriptdeobfuscateunminify+2

Start Course

Hacker

4

### Extract macOS Apps

Get inside any macOS application. Extract resources, assets, icons, and analyze binaries.

macosappdmg+2

Start Course

Hacker

5

### Reverse Engineering Tools

The essential toolkit for reverse engineering. Ghidra, Hopper, Frida, and more - what each does and when to use it.

ghidrahopperfrida+3

Start Course

Hacker

6

### Terminal Scripts & Hacks

Practical scripts your coding agent can build and run. DNS benchmarking, network diagnostics, file automation, and more.

scriptsterminaldns+3

Start Course

Hacker

7

### Web Scraping & Data Extraction

Have your coding agent build scrapers for any website. Extract data, handle pagination, export to CSV/JSON.

scrapingdatapython+3

Start Course

Hacker

8

### API Reverse Engineering

Figure out how apps communicate with their servers. Discover undocumented APIs and build your own clients.

apireverse engineeringproxy+2

Start Course

Hacker

9

### Browser Automation

Automate anything you do in a browser. Your coding agent builds Playwright scripts that click, type, and navigate for you.

automationplaywrightbrowser+2

Start Course

© 2025 Ken Kai

content.text:
Perfect! I've extracted the course information from the Hacker section. The document shows 9 courses in the Hacker section. However, I notice the file doesn't contain the actual URLs - it appears to be a markdown representation of the rendered page with "Start Course" buttons but no href attributes.

Based on the structure and the mentioned courses, here's what I found:

## Hacker Section Courses (9 items):

1. **Extract Chrome Extensions** (Item 1)
2. **Extract Electron Apps** (Item 2)
3. **JavaScript Deobfuscation** (Item 3)
4. **Extract macOS Apps** (Item 4)
5. **Reverse Engineering Tools** (Item 5)
6. **Terminal Scripts & Hacks** (Item 6)
7. **Web Scraping & Data Extraction** (Item 7)
8. **API Reverse Engineering** (Item 8)
9. **Browser Automation** (Item 9)

## URL Pattern Analysis:

Based on typical web patterns and the course structure, the URL format would likely be:
```
https://www.kenkais.com/exclusive/hacker/{course-slug}
```

Where course slugs would be (inferred from titles):
- `extract-chrome-extensions`
- `extract-electron-apps`
- `javascript-deobfuscation`
- `extract-macos-apps`
